p.text: The Supreme Court of New South Wales as formerly established as the superior court of record in New South Wales is hereby continued.
The Court shall have all jurisdiction which may be necessary for the administration of justice in New South Wales.

The jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of New South Wales was established under the terms of the Act 4 George IV c 96 and the Third Charter of Justice for New South Wales issued in 1823. This conferred on the court all the jurisdiction of the King's Bench, Common Pleas and Exchequer in England as well as jurisdiction in Chancery, Probate and with certain exceptions, ecclesiastical matters. Under the present section the court has a wide jurisdiction to do all that is necessary for the administration of justice in New South Wales. Arguably this is a wider jurisdiction than existed under the Charter of Justice — although the practical significance of any difference may be difficult to discern: see Tait v R (1962) 108 CLR 620; 36 ALJR 330 (jurisdiction to make preservation orders in administrative law proceedings may have been possessed, in any event, by any superior court). The amplitude of the jurisdiction conferred by the present section encourages the view that the Supreme Court is a court of unlimited jurisdiction. But the reality is that no court in the federal judicial system has an unlimited original jurisdiction: Stack v Coast Securities (No 9) Pty Ltd (1983) 46 ALR 451 at 460; (1983) ATPR ¶40-342 (the jurisdiction of all courts is limited by their constitutional competence).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 23.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 39.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Pt IVA, Pt V, Divs 1, 1A.
(CTH) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.
(NSW) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.

Subject to certain limitations (relating principally to treaty matters and intergovernmental proceedings) s 39 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) confers federal jurisdiction on state courts in all matters that are within the original, non-exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court, and all matters in which original jurisdiction could be conferred upon the High Court. In addition, specific federal statutes confer jurisdiction on state courts in particular matters (for example, the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987 (Cth) gave state courts jurisdiction under, amongst other things, Pt IVA , Pt IVB and Divs 1 and 1A of Pt V of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (see now ss 86 and 138B of the Competition and Consumer Act 2010). But the most comprehensive grant of federal and interstate jurisdiction on state courts is contained in the cross-vesting legislative scheme. The scheme consists of complementary federal and state legislation including the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 (Cth) , the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 (NSW) and the Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Act 1999. As it was originally enacted, the cross-vesting legislation provided for a substantial interchangeability of jurisdiction between the Supreme Courts of the states, the Supreme Courts of the territories, the Family Court and the Federal Court. Part of the original scheme was declared invalid in Re Wakim: Ex parte McNally (1998) CLR 511; (1999) 163 ALR 270; 31 ACSR 99 , in so far as it attempted to confer state jurisdiction on the federal courts. That invalidity led to the enactment of the Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Act 1999, which provided a mechanism for the enforcement of prior judgments of federal courts under the scheme and also dealt with the transfer of pending proceedings from the federal courts. Under the altered cross-vesting scheme, any of the state and territory Supreme Courts may (subject to limited exceptions) exercise all of the original and appellate jurisdiction of every other such court. And they also have the original and appellate jurisdiction of the Federal and Family Courts (subject to restrictions relating to “special federal matters”. There are provisions for the transfer of proceedings between courts (ss 5 and 6) and also provisions relating to the choice of rules of procedure and evidence in the exercise of cross-vested jurisdiction (s 11). Judgments given by any court exercising cross-vested jurisdiction are enforceable throughout Australia (s 14).

The Supreme Court is a superior court of record. As such it has an inherent jurisdiction in addition to its specific statutory jurisdiction: see K Mason QC, “The Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court” (1983) 57 ALJ 449; see also “The Inherent Jurisdiction to Regulate Civil Proceedings” by M S Dockery (1997) 13 LQR 120. The inherent jurisdiction is a function of the Supreme Court's position as a superior court with responsibility for the administration of justice. As such, the jurisdiction is wide and incapable of being confined to defined and closed categories: Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 at 344 ; Reid v Howard (1995) 184 CLR 1 at 16; 131 ALR 609 at 619 . For that reason the expression “inherent jurisdiction” has been described as “an uncertain expression loosely used and signifying a discretionary power which may be developed to meet circumstances not known to nineteenth century judges”: Home Office v Harman [1981] 1 QB 534; see also R v Forbes; Ex parte Bevan (1972) 127 CLR 1; [1972] ALR 1046 . Nevertheless, some fundamental points can be made about the concept of inherent jurisdiction. First, although only a superior court of record has inherent jurisdiction in the strict sense, all courts have an incidental power to control their own process. (For an examination of the concept of inherent jurisdiction of a court, and of the distinction between a superior court and a court of limited jurisdiction, see Grassby v R (1989) 168 CLR 1; 87 ALR 618 , per Dawson J. See also Ex parte Currie; Re Dempsey [1970] 1 NSWR 617; (1969) 70 SR (NSW) 443 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 465; Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 ; and see [SCA s 23.5] and [SCA s 23.25] below.) Second, the jurisdiction is limited by the requirements of the administration of justice. It cannot, for example, be used to excuse compliance with statutory obligations or prevent the exercise of statutory authority: Doyle v Commonwealth (1985) 156 CLR 510 at 518; 60 ALR 567 ; Landsal Pty Ltd (in liq) v REI Building Society (now Co-op Building Society of South Australia) (1993) 41 FCR 421; 113 ALR 643 at 650 (Fed C of A). Similarly neither the inherent jurisdiction nor this section can be used to abrogate a fundamental common law right: Reid v Howard (1995) 184 CLR 1 at 16; 131 ALR 609 (no power to circumvent the privilege against self incrimination): Vasil v National Australia Bank Ltd (1999) 46 NSWLR 207; [1999] NSWCA 161; BC9902847 (disclosure order in aid of Mareva preservation order set aside as inconsistent with the privilege against incrimination).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 23.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 28.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.7, r 23.9, r 33.4, r 4.15, r 14.28, r 42.21, r 42.5, r 5.3.

The content of the court's inherent jurisdiction, and the essential nature of the concept, is best appreciated by considering examples of the matters that it has been held to include. However, when considering these examples it is important to bear in mind the conceptual distinction between “inherent” and “incidental” powers: see [SCA s 23.5] . That distinction has not always been observed in the authorities: Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13 at 16–17 . Subject to that qualification, examples of the court's inherent jurisdiction include the following:
to refer proceedings, with the consent of the parties, to arbitration: Buckley v Bennell Design & Constructions Pty Ltd (1978) 140 CLR 1 at 7; 19 ALR 257 at 263; BC7800036 per Barwick CJ;

to order non-publication of proceedings in a statutory court or tribunal: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 50 ACSR 380; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 at [29] per Spigelman CJ; contrast SG v DPP [2003] NSWSC 413; BC200302525 at [11]–[18] ; on appeal SG v DPP [2003] NSWCA 128; BC200302455 at [3] ;
to permit intervention in proceedings (see [SCA s 23.30] and [6.24.50]–[6.24.70] of the UCPR);

to strike out scandalous and irrelevant matters in court documents (Cracknall v Janson (1879) 11 Ch D 1 at 13; 27 WR 851 ; Rossage v Rossage [1960] 1 All ER 600; [1960] 1 WLR 249 ); see UCPR r 4.15 and notes [4.15.5]–[4.15.30] ;
to vary interlocutory agreements between the parties (Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 at 579 ; EI Du Pont de Nemours & Co v Cmr of Patents (1987) 16 FCR 423; 83 ALR 499 );
to adjourn proceedings (Hinckley & South Leicestershire Permanent Benefit Building Society v Freeman [1941] Ch 32; [1940] 4 All ER 212 );

to make self-executing orders (Allen v Sir Alfred McAlpine & Sons Ltd [1968] 2 QB 229; [1968] 1 All ER 543; Turner v Bulletin Newspaper Co Pty Ltd (1974) 131 CLR 69; 3 ALR 491; BC7400037 ; Birkett v James [1978] AC 297; [1977] 2 All ER 801 );
to extend time to comply with procedural requirements (Biala Pty Ltd v Mallina Holdings Ltd [1989] 2 WAR 381);

to order summary judgment (Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050 ; Little v Law Institute of Victoria [1990] VR 257 at 261; (1989) Aust Tort Reports ¶80-250 ; Nixon v W Phelan & Son Pty Ltd [1959] VR 83 );
to award costs (Knight v FP Special Assets Ltd (1992) 174 CLR 178 at 182–3, 193–4; 107 ALR 585 at 587, 596–7; BC9202673 ; Rajski v Computer Manufacture & Design Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 443);

to set aside a default, or irregularly obtained, judgment (see [SCA s 81.5] , [SCR 40.9.15] ; Evans v Bartlam [1937] AC 473; [1937] 2 All ER 646 ; Cameron v Cole (1944) 68 CLR 571 at 589; [1944] ALR 130 ; Permanent Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (Executor estate of Andrews) v Stocks & Holdings (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1976) 15 ACTR 45 at 48; 28 FLR 195 at 198 ; Dsane v Hagan [1961] 3 All ER 380 at 384; Bradvica v Radulovic [1975] VR 434 at 441 );

to amend a judgment to correct an error (Taylor v Taylor (1979) 143 CLR 1 at 16; 25 ALR 418 ; Haig v Minister administering the National Parks and Wildlife Act (1994) 85 LGERA 143 at 153–4 ; Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13 at 16–17, 27–8 );
to deal with contempt (John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd v McRae (1955) 93 CLR 351; [1955] ALR 265; BC5500130 ; Re Wright (No 1) [1968] VR 164 );

to stay pending appeal (Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685 at 692; 10 ACLR 42; Ellis v Scott [1964] 2 All ER 987; [1964] 1 WLR 976; Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 at 345 ; Fulcher v Hilt (1985) 66 ALR 96; 60 ALJR 278 (stay of extradition order pending determination of application for special leave to appeal to High Court); Re AGL Gas Networks Ltd (2001) 160 FLR 269; 37 ACSR 441 (approval of scheme of arrangement));

to exercise jurisdiction over its practitioners (Myers v Elman [1940] AC 282 at 289; [1939] 4 All ER 484 (costs order against a solicitor); Holden & Co (a firm) v Crown Prosecution Service [1990] 2 WLR 1137; Knight v FP Special Assets Ltd (1992) 174 CLR 178 at 199; 107 ALR 585 at 600–1; BC9202673 ; Whyte v Brosch (1998) 45 NSWLR 354 (failure to file appeal submissions and chronologies));
to make declaratory orders (Ainsworth v Criminal Justice Commission (1992) 175 CLR 564 at 581; 106 ALR 11 at 22 );

to deal with the custody and guardianship of children: Director-General, Dept of Community Services v Y [1999] NSWSC 644; BC9903731 ; Re Frances and Benny [2005] NSWSC 1207; BC200510266 at [17] ; Director-General, Dept of Community Services; Re Thomas (2009) 41 Fam LR 220; [2009] NSWSC 217; BC200902041 (protective jurisdiction extends to ordering involuntary detention of child in secure accommodation);

possibly, to order removal of proceedings from a lower court: Buzera Pty Ltd v Mezan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1998) NSW ConvR ¶55-851; BC9800722 (necessary to show that removal was essential for the administration of justice); and

to exercise a protective jurisdiction over incapable persons: Secretary, Dept of Health and Community Services v JWB and SMB (1992) 175 CLR 218; 106 ALR 385 ; including jurisdiction to authorise medical procedures being carried out on disabled persons: see MAW v Western Sydney Area Health Service (2000) 49 NSWLR 231; 26 Fam LR 364 (refusal of application for the collection of sperm from a comatose person: Northbridge v Central Sydney Area Health Service (2000) 50 NSWLR 549; [2000] NSWSC 1241; BC200008272 ; (order that an unconscious man be provided with medical treatment directed towards preserving his life));

to stay other adjudicative proceedings that involve abuse of process, unfair oppression or breach of the rules of natural justice: Herron v McGregor (1986) 6 NSWLR 246 (medical disciplinary tribunal proceedings — long delay in prosecuting complaints — abuse of process); Gill v Walton (1991) 25 NSWLR 190 (medical disciplinary tribunal — previously stayed complaints renewed after Royal Commission — death of witnesses — unfairly oppressive proceedings); Walton v Gardiner (1993) 177 CLR 378; 112 ALR 289; BC9303612 (power to stay proceedings involving unacceptable injustice — not limited to improper purpose or unlikelihood of fair hearing); Zurich Australian Insurance Ltd v Motor Accidents Authority of NSW [2009] NSWSC 1314; BC200910951 at [8] (assessment under the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 — alleged denial of procedural fairness — stay denied).

Any court has, as an incident of its jurisdiction, power to do whatever is necessary to enable it to act effectively within that jurisdiction and control its own process and proceedings: Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254 at 1301; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 ; Watson v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 685; 28 A Crim R 332 (stay of criminal proceedings); Logwon Pty Ltd v Warringah Shire Council (1993) 33 NSWLR 13 at 16–17, 27–8 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 465 at 476; Hammond v Scheinberg (2001) 52 NSWLR 49 at 52; [2001] NSWSC 568; BC200103695 ; (granting media access to affidavits); Bogeta Pty Ltd v Wales [1977] 1 NSWLR 139 at 149; Metropolitan Bank Ltd v Pooley (1885) 10 App Cas 210 at 214; [1881–5] All ER Rep 949 ; Reichel v Magrath (1889) 14 App Cas 665; Taylor v A-G [1975] 2 NZLR 675 at 670, 682, 689; Taylor v Taylor (1979) 143 CLR 1 at 5; 25 ALR 418 at 422 ; R v Forbes; Ex parte Bevan (1972) 127 CLR 1 at 7; [1972] ALR 1046 at 1048 ; Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162 CLR 612; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781 ; Mills v Cooper [1967] 2 QB 459 at 467; [1967] 2 All ER 100 at 106. See also Abse v Smith [1986] QB 536; [1986] 1 All ER 350 and the judgment of Santow J in Director-General, Dept of Community Services v Boehm (NSWSC, Santow J, No 2836/97, 13 August 1997, unreported, BC9703792) and the cases cited therein.

This section may be sufficient to empower the court to permit intervention in proceedings of persons who are not originally parties: Shales v Lieschke (1985) 3 NSWLR 65 at 80–1, 90; 10 Fam LR 261 ; United States Tobacco Co v Minister for Consumer Affairs (1988) 20 FCR 520; 83 ALR 79 ; Rushby v Roberts [1983] 1 NSWLR 350 per Street CJ, contra Hutley JA, cf Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391; Pegang Mining Co Ltd v Choon Sam [1969] 2 MLJ 52, see [SCR 8.8.12] . As to intervention by the Crown where questions of the public interest arise, see Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1 at 43; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Attorney-General (UK) v Heinemann Publishers Australia Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Powell J, No 4382/85, 25 November 1986, unreported, BC8600518). As to intervention by amicus curiae, see R v Murphy (1986) 5 NSWLR 18 and [6.24.60] behind guidecard “Uniform Civil Procedure Rules”.

In Re S (1988) 6 BPR 13,781, an order was made appointing a receiver and trustee of an accountant's practice, in reliance on this section. The accountant was a sole practitioner ill in hospital and may have had a trust account defalcation. The court held that this section gave power to make any order which is “in furtherance of the interests of justice”. As to the more specific statutory power to appoint a receiver, see the notes to s 67 of the Supreme Court Act at [SCA s 67.5] .

The court may set aside interlocutory directions by an arbitrator: Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd (1995) 36 NSWLR 662; 120 FLR 171; BC9504837 ; not following Bremer Vulkan Schiffbau und Maschinenfabrik v South India Shipping Corp Ltd [1981] AC 909 .

The internal arrangements of superior courts of record have always been matters within the inherent jurisdiction of the courts, subject to any relevant statutory provisions: Rajski v Wood (1989) 18 NSWLR 512 .

It is a principle of statutory construction that a superior court of general jurisdiction will not be deprived of jurisdiction except by express words or necessary implication: Law Society of New South Wales v Weaver [1974] 1 NSWLR 271; North Sydney Municipal Council v Comfytex [1975] 1 NSWLR 447 at 450; Designbuild Australia Pty Ltd v Endeavour Resources Ltd (1980) 5 ACLR 610; Electric Light & Power Supply Corp Ltd v Electricity Commission of New South Wales (1956) 94 CLR 554; [1956] ALR 614 ; Forster v Jododex Australia Pty Ltd (1972) 127 CLR 421 at 435; [1972] ALR 1303 ; DMW v CGW (1982) 151 CLR 491 at 509; 44 ALR 225 at 237 ; Nomad Industries of Australia Pty Ltd v Federal Cmr of Taxation [1983] 2 NSWLR 56; (1983) 51 ALR 95 . Where there is no express statutory exclusion of the court's jurisdiction, no objection to jurisdiction can be made unless it can positively be established that the relevant jurisdiction has been conferred on some other court: Board v Board [1919] AC 956 at 962–3 ; Re Totalisator Administration Board of Queensland [1989] 1 Qd R 215; (1988) 80 ALR 73 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 23.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Land and Environment Court Act 1979 s 71.
(NSW) Landlord and Tenant Act 1899 s 2A.

Various Acts dealing with specialist tribunals take away the jurisdiction of the court in whole or in part. See, for example, s 71 of the Land and Environment Court Act 1979, which provides that certain proceedings within that court's jurisdiction may not be commenced or entertained in the Supreme Court and s 19 of the Consumer Claims Tribunals Act 1974 which deprives courts generally of jurisdiction where a consumer claim has been referred to a Consumer Claims Tribunal. See also s 2A of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1899 which restricts proceedings for possession by landlords in the Supreme Court to leases where the rent exceeds $25.20 per week.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 24] s 24 Court to have powers of Judges, etc

leg:heading.title: Court to have powers of Judges, etc

p.text: In this section “special office” means the office of Chief Judge in Equity, Chief Judge in Divorce, Probate Judge, and any other special judicial office in the Court.

Where, under the law in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, any power is vested in the Judges collectively, or in any two or more Judges, or in any Judge in special office, or in any Judge—

that power shall be exercised by the Court in all respects as those Judges or that Judge might have exercised the power immediately before the commencement of this Act, but in accordance with this Act and the rules;
the Court shall have power co-ordinate with the power of those Judges or that Judge; and
subject to paragraphs (a) and (b) , that power shall not be exercised by those Judges or that Judge.

Where, under the law in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, any power is vested in the Court, whether generally or in any jurisdiction of the Court, that power shall be exercised by the Court in all respects as the Court might have exercised the power immediately before the commencement of this Act, but in accordance with this Act and the rules.
This section has effect even though—
in the case of a power vested in a Judge in special office, the special office has been abolished, whether before or after the commencement of this Act, or the special office is vacant;

the power in question is vested in the Court as a designated Court, in the Judges collectively or any two or more Judges as designated persons, or in any Judge in special office or any Judge as a designated person; or
exercise of the power is expressed under the law in force immediately before the commencement of this Act to be final or without appeal.

This section applies to a power which, immediately before the commencement of this Act, is exercisable by rule nisi or rule absolute in any proceedings or by other rule in the nature of an order or direction in any proceedings, but otherwise does not apply to a power to make rules.
This section does not apply to a power—
vested in the Chief Justice as Chief Justice;
[repealed]
vested in a Judge as chairman, or additional temporary chairman, of the Crown Employees Appeal Board;
vested in a Judge in special office or other Judge as member (whether chairman or otherwise) of a board, committee or other body of persons not composed wholly of Judges.
[subr (6) am Act 205 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 2 Pt 1]

The Governor may direct by proclamation published in the Gazette that this section shall not apply to any power specified in that proclamation, being a power arising under any Act or Imperial Act in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, and the proclamation shall have effect accordingly, but subject to section 41 of the Interpretation Act 1987.
[subs (7) am Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32 ; Act 56 of 2009 Sch 4.71[1], effective 17 July 2009]
Sections 40 and 41 of the Interpretation Act 1987 apply to a proclamation under subsection (7) in the same way as they apply to a statutory rule within the meaning of that Act.
[subs (8) subst Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32 ; am Act 56 of 2009 Sch 4.71[2], effective 17 July 2009]
[subs (9) rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]
[subs (10) rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]

Statutory provisions sometimes confer jurisdiction specifically upon the Supreme Court and sometimes are expressed to confer jurisdiction upon a judge of the court. The difference could give rise to a question whether the power had been conferred on the court, on the judge as persona designata or to a particular judge, eg, the Chief Judge in Equity: see, eg, Ex parte Jones (1874) 12 SCR (NSW) L 284 and Re Calman and John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd (1953) 54 SR (NSW) 86 . This section (subject to the provisos in subs (6)) vests all such powers in the court as constituted under this Act.
